This is a call to action to help protect our Great Lakes.   Canada is considering allowing radioactive waste to be stored underground right next to the Great Lakes - What a terrible idea!   As many of you know, I have been a strong advocate for protecting our Great Lakes. My reason has always been simple: the Great Lakes systems contains 20% of the worlds fresh water. It is a place where people swim, fish, and most importantly, get their drinking water. We need to protect it. So the idea that we would allow radioactive waste to be buried underground right next to one of the lakes is ludicrous.   A bipartisan group of members from the Great Lakes region, including myself, has written two letters on the subject. The first was to President Trump asking him to intervene on this matter. The second was to the Canadian government, asking them to consider the ramifications of this decision. We could use more help on this issue.   Please lend us a hand and reach out to the State Department and Canadian government and ask them to protect our Great Lakes. Last night, two bills I co-sponsored passed the House of Representatives: The WINGMAN Act and The Hire Vets Act. These pieces of legislation are vital to the wellbeing of our nation’s veterans, and I was proud to be a cosponsor of both.  The Hire Vets Act creates a voluntary awards program to recognize the meaningful, verifiable efforts undertaken by employers, both large and small, to hire and retain veterans. These “HIRE Vets Medallions” would be awarded to deserving employers who make critical contributions to our veteran workforce. Applicants would have to pay fees to help cover the costs of the program.    The WINGMAN Act permits veterans to grant certain designated congressional employees access to their records in the databases of the Veterans Benefits Administration. The goal of this legislation is to help clear the backlog of veterans claims at the VA by giving congressional staffers the tools to more efficiently assist veterans.   Both of these bills are common sense measures to help our nation’s veterans; I look forward to the Senate quickly passing them so they can go to the President’s desk to be signed into law.

It would be a disaster if Asian carp make it into the Great Lakes.  Our region relies on the $7 billion sport fishing market, $16 billion boating industry and the $18 billion hunting and wildlife observation market. The introduction of Asian carp would decimate these industries and have other negative impacts.  I respectfully urge the President to direct the Army Corp to work with state and local governments as well as other industry-related groups to find a long-term solution to preserve and protect our Great Lakes.
I continue to call on the administration to present a budget to Congress which fully funds the Great Lakes Restoration Initiative.

As you may know, Asian carp is threatening to enter the Great Lakes ecosystem via the Mississippi River and other tributaries.  The U.S. is taking the threat to its $7-billion Great Lakes fishery very seriously. In 2015 alone, the Asian Carp Regional Coordinating Committee (ACRCC) funded mainly by the states bordering the Great Lakes and the U.S. federal government, spent $74-million on 43 different projects designed to control Asian carp.  The problem is that federal funding is under attack. A vast amount of funding to protect the Great Lakes comes from the $300 million Great Lakes Restoration Initiative (GLRI). The same GLRI legislation that I introduced last Congress and was passed by Congress and signed into law.  Rumors are trickling out that the new administration’s first budget will cut the GLRI down to the bone.  Fighting for this funding, though, is nothing new. Under President Obama we had to annually find more than $50 million to make the program whole.   The fight will now continue under the Trump administration, as regional programs like the GLRI are under assault.

Last week, the House passed legislation to remove the termination date for the Veterans Choice Program.  This is a vital program that was established in 2014 that allows eligible veterans to seek medical care from private health-care providers. The program was set to expire on August 7th, but our vote last week removed the expiration date and extends the program to provide valuable continuity for our nation's veterans.  Under the program, a veteran who is  seeking an appointment but unable to obtain care from the VA within 30 days or lives more than 40 miles from a VA facility, can receive care from certain private and federally sponsored providers.  Since the inception of the program three years ago, more than 1.2 million veterans have used the program, according to a report from the House Veterans’ Affairs Committee.  To me, this is commonsense legislation that provides imperative access to care to those who have given so much to our country.

Here is why I could not support the AHCA and voted no today.   The AHCA does not do enough to bring down the cost of healthcare delivery.  The idea that premiums could potentially skyrocket for people with pre-existing conditions and increase 3 to 5 times for people nearing retirement is something I find unacceptable.   Another take away is how this bill would adversely affect the progress we have made to combat our opioid crisis. Our state leads the nation in opioid deaths. This bill threatens our essential health care benefits, including opioid addiction treatment.   These issues are not amenable to a quick fix. We need to take the time necessary to hold hearings and work together on a step by step basis to develop a long term solution that works for everyone.   I will always keep an open mind on working to repeal the federal government-controlled healthcare system and replace it with a patient centered bill that has real reforms and makes health care more accessible and affordable to all Ohio families.

The President’s budget, like always, will once again receive significant alterations. As I have said now under two different presidents, as outlined in the Constitution, the Congress, not the Executive Branch, has the ‘power of the purse’.   As a member of the House Appropriations Committee I take that responsibility very seriously. It is my job to analyze the budget, go through each and every line item, question every witness, and demand spending justifications on behalf of the taxpayers who are footing the bill. After that, Congress will begin the process of actually deciding how to spend that money on items like our Great Lakes, meals on wheels and the defense of our country.     Now I do applaud President Trump's effort in submitting a balanced budget, as well as his commitment towards a stronger military and greater accountability of taxpayer dollars. I look forward to reviewing the president’s request in greater detail.

For the first time in more than a decade, we’ve passed a complete government funding bill on time. Today, my colleagues and I passed H.R. 3354, the Make America Secure and Prosperous Act. As a member of the House Appropriations Committee, the passage of this bill is the culmination of nine months of markups, hearings, and long nights in committee.   Here are some highlights of the package: ✔️ Fully funds the president’s border wall request. ✔️ Beefs up enforcement against illegal immigration. ✔️ Prioritizes our national defense to help rebuild our military. ✔️Gives our troops a much needed and deserved pay raise. ✔️ Ends dozens of underachieving government programs across multiple agencies and reduces funding for hundreds of others that need improvement. ✔️ Supports the exploration of space by funding NASA and NASA Science programs which help NASA Glenn Research Center, one of our region’s biggest job creators. ✔️ Fully funds the Great Lake Restoration Initiative (GLRI) to help protect Lake Erie and 20 percent of the world’s fresh surface water supply.
